results.title: Monkey on the back
results.creator_credit: Grant McLean, ONF | NFB and Julian Biggs
results.brief_description: This documentary drama, based on the real-life experiences of a drug addict, not only portrays the terrible consequences of the misuse of narcotics but presents the general problem of addiction and, particularly, of the addict as an individual. Dick Smith lost everything valued most in life because of his craving for the narcotics which finally killed him. In relating the story of his attempts to break the habit, the film reveals the essential nature of addiction as both a social and a human problem.

results.title: Monkey Grip
results.creator_credit: Patricia Lovell, Pavilion Films and Ken Cameron
results.brief_description: Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless artists who refuse to live by the conventional rules.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Patricia Lovell, Pavilion Films and Ken Cameron
results.description:
Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city in the early 1980s. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless musicians, actors and writers who refuse to live by the conventional rules. Noni Hazelhurst received an AFI Best Actress Award for her performance in 1982.

Starring Noni Hazelhurst, Colin Friels, Harold Hopkins, Candy Raymond, Michael Caton, Tim Burns, Cathy Downes, Lisa Peers, Din Miller-Robinson, Alice Garner and Christina Amphlett from the ‘Divinyls’. Adapted from Helen Garner’s novel ‘Monkey Grip’ by Ken Cameron in association with Helen Garner. Cinematography by David Gribble. Editing by David Huggett.
description_for_label:
Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city in the early 1980s. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless musicians, actors and writers who refuse to live by the conventional rules. Noni Hazelhurst received an AFI Best Actress Award for her performance in 1982.

Starring Noni Hazelhurst, Colin Friels, Harold Hopkins, Candy Raymond, Michael Caton, Tim Burns, Cathy Downes, Lisa Peers, Din Miller-Robinson, Alice Garner and Christina Amphlett from the ‘Divinyls’. Adapted from Helen Garner’s novel ‘Monkey Grip’ by Ken Cameron in association with Helen Garner. Cinematography by David Gribble. Editing by David Huggett.

results.title: Monkey business: primates
results.creator_credit: Chris O'Rourke, Victoria. Education Dept. Curriculum Branch and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Discusses features common to the three main groups of primates. Also provides a behind-the scenes look at the work of the keepers in the primate department of Melbourne zoo.

results.title: Monkey business
results.creator_credit: Sol Siegel, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Howard Hawks
results.brief_description: Marilyn Monroe, Cary Grant, Ginger Rogers and Charles Coburn star in the zany Howard Hawks comedy about a chemist who discovers a potent rejuvenation drug. Dr. Barnaby Fulton is a staid scientist working on a youth restoring serum with no success when one of the laboratory chimpanzees accidentally concocts the formula. Fulton and his wife try it with hilarious results and successive doses result in increasingly more juvenile behaviour. When others taste the potion, including Fulton’s stuffy boss and his voluptuous secretary, the laboratory really goes wild!

results.title: Monica Street
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
This animated short story features a girls’ journey walking along a street called ‘Monica Street’. She encounters an art gallery; music shop and a costume shop. The end of her journey sees her being invited to a Jewish meal at her friend’s house.

results.title: Monica Goermann: gymnast
results.creator_credit: Jacques Bobet, ONF | NFB and Steven Keller
results.brief_description: Monica Goermann is a young Winipeg gymnast who is on her way to becoming an international celebrity. Under the watchful supervision of her mother, who is also her coach, Monica trains daily, executing difficult moves with superhuman control. In this film she is shown preparing for the 1978 Commonwealth Games at Edmonton, where she tied for the Siver Medal.

results.title: Monica's seaside adventures
results.creator_credit: Monica Trapaga, Monica and the Moochers and Ignatius Jones
results.brief_description: A feast of summery beach songs designed to get small children toe-tapping and dancing. Monica’s crazy friends include Ted, McKaw, Compost bin, Fridge and Dr. Wango Tango. Bring your bathers and groove to the “Beach Boogaloo”, make waves at the “Sand Crab’s Disco” and learn “‘Sid Shark’s Step”.

results.title: Mongolia. Ep. 2. The City on the Steppes
results.creator_credit: Brian Moser, Mongolian Television and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
The Mongolian People’s Republic which began with the Revolution of 1921, was once domoinated by nomadic herdsmen but today is becoming a self-sufficient, agricultural and industrial nation. Of the one and a half million people, about a quarter live in the capital city of Ulan Bator. Anthropologist Owen Lattimre looks at life in Ulan Bator including cultural activities, horse racing and schooling. Highlights the recognition of women at work, production and education.
